support.p: Memorial pillar; no dimensions are given in the original publication. “The records are incised on long narrow slabs of stone, and in the majority of cases the inscriptions are incised lengthwise... it is apparent that the mason did not take the trouble to make [the inscribed surfaces] smooth before incising the letters.”

layout.p: 1' 8" 1' 10" ; the average length of the letters is 1 1/4".

provenance.p: Discovered by Mr. D. R. Bhandarkar at Bhuj, “in the stored of the Engineering Department, near the palace.”

Originally these inscriptions were located at Andhau, in Khāvḍā, standing on a hillock, but they were “removed to Bhuj by the late Dewāṇ Ranchhodbhāī Udairām, who was very keen on antiquarian matters.”

div.p: This edition and translation is based on Banerji 1921–1922.

In the year fifty-two, 50 ,2; on the second day of the dark half of Phālguna, va . 2, of (the reign of) the king Rudradāman, son of Jayadāman, (the grandson) of the king Cāṣṭana, son of Ysāmotika, (this) staff was raised (in memory) of Ṛṣabhadeva, son of Siṃhila of the Opaśati gotra, by his brother Madana, son of Siṃhila.
